guide.conclusion: This project first appeared in MAKE Volume 29, page 123.

flags.title: From MAKE Magazine
flags.text: This project first appeared on the pages of MAKE magazine.

guide.introduction: Calling a rocket that sprints over 100 feet into the air a “toy” might be a bit of a stretch. Toy or not, this rocket really packs a punch. Fly it using the Compressed Air Rocket launcher from MAKE Volume 15 (get the kit at makezine.com/go/launcherkit) or a stomp rocket launcher (makezine.com/go/stomplauncher).
guide.introduction_rendered:
Calling a rocket that sprints over 100 feet into the air a “toy” might be a bit of a stretch. Toy or not, this rocket really packs a punch. Fly it using the Compressed Air Rocket launcher from MAKE Volume 15 (get the kit at makezine.com/go/launcherkit) or a stomp rocket launcher (makezine.com/go/stomplauncher).

Relevant parts
  • Foam pipe insulation
  • Foam sheet
  • Zip tie
  • Duct tape
  • Packing tape
Tools
  • Hot glue gun
  • Scissors

parts.notes: You can build 8 rockets with a 6' piece (instructions here are for one rocket).
available at craft stores or online

steps.title: Cut the foam and cinch with a zip tie.

lines.text: Cut a 9" section of foam pipe insulation. Wrap the zip tie 1/2" from one end and cinch it tight so no air will escape. Trim the excess foam above the cinched-off end.
lines.text_raw: Cut a 9" section of foam pipe insulation. Wrap the zip tie 1/2" from one end and cinch it tight so no air will escape. Trim the excess foam above the cinched-off end.

steps.title: Apply duct tape to foam rocket body.

lines.text: Criss-cross 2 pieces of duct tape over the cinched end. Now cover the entire foam section with duct tape spanning the length. Three overlapping pieces of tape should do the trick.
lines.text_raw: Criss-cross 2 pieces of duct tape over the cinched end. Now cover the entire foam section with duct tape spanning the length. Three overlapping pieces of tape should do the trick.

lines.text: Cut a 4"×1½" rectangle from the foam sheet, then cut it diagonally to make 2 fins. Repeat. Using generous amounts of hot glue, attach 3 of the fins, spaced evenly, onto the foam rocket body tube. If the glue doesn’t stick well to the rough duct tape, wrap 2 strips of clear packing tape over the duct tape around the bottom of the rocket to create a smooth surface for gluing the fins.
lines.text_raw: Cut a 4"×1½" rectangle from the foam sheet, then cut it diagonally to make 2 fins. Repeat. Using generous amounts of hot glue, attach 3 of the fins, spaced evenly, onto the foam rocket body tube. If the glue doesn’t stick well to the rough duct tape, wrap 2 strips of clear packing tape over the duct tape around the bottom of the rocket to create a smooth surface for gluing the fins.

lines.text: Pressurize the compressed air launcher for 45psi–65psi, and launch. (For a lower pressure/altitude launch, use a stomp launcher.) When the duct tape finally fails with a spectacular blowout, just apply more duct tape over the blown section and keep flying!
lines.text_raw: Pressurize the compressed air launcher for 45psi–65psi, and launch. (For a lower pressure/altitude launch, use a stomp launcher.) When the duct tape finally fails with a spectacular blowout, just apply more duct tape over the blown section and keep flying!

guide.summary: Toy or not, this rocket really packs a punch.
guide.title: High-Pressure Foam Rocket
